Channel 8 (+1) | sat serv 1 = [[Sky (UK & Ireland)|Sky]] | sat chan 1 = Channel 101 ([[Republic of Ireland|IRL]])
Channel 161 ([[Northern Ireland|NI]]) | sat serv 2 = SCTV Digital | sat chan 2 = Channel 101 | cable serv 1 = [[UPC Ireland]] | cable chan 1 = Channel 101 | cable serv 2 = [[Virgin Media]] (UK) | cable chan 2 = Channel 875 ([[Northern Ireland|NI]] only) | adsl serv 1 = [[Magnet Entertainment]] | adsl chan 1 = Channel 101 | sat radio serv 1 = | sat radio chan 1 = | iptv serv 1 = | iptv chan 1 = | online serv 1 = | online chan 1 = | 3gmobile serv 1 = }} '''RTÃ One''' (Irish: ''RTÃ a hAon'') is the flagship television channel of [[RaidiÃ³ TeilifÃ­s Ãireann]] (RTÃ), and it is the most popular and most watched television channel in [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]]. It was launched as ''TelefÃ­s Ãireann'' on 31 December 1961, it was renamed ''RTÃ Television'' in 1966, and it was renamed as RTÃ One upon the launch of RTÃ Two in 1978. RTÃ is funded partly by the licence fee, the remainder of the funding is provided by commercial advertising, because RTÃ is funded partly by the licence fee it shows considerably fewer advertisements than most other channels available in [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]]. Its headquarters is at [[Donnybrook, Dublin]]. RTÃ One is almost universally available on the [[Very high frequency|VHF]] and [[Ultra high frequency|UHF]] bands in the Republic of Ireland (though VHF has mostly been phased out), and it is also available on the most digital television services available in the Republic of Ireland such as [[Sky (UK & Ireland)|Sky Ireland]], [[UPC Ireland]], [[Magnet Networks]], and [[Saorview]]. It is available in most of Northern Ireland via analogue overspill, Sky and [[Virgin Media]]. ==History== The station began life as ''TelefÃ­s Ãireann'' in 1961.{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/laweb/brc/brc_1960s.html|title=TELEFÃS ÃIREANN, IRELAND'S NATIONAL TELEVISION STATION, GOES ON AIR: 31 DECEMBER 1961|publisher=RTÃ Archives|accessdate=24 April 2010}} The very first show of all to be pre-recorded for the new television service was The School Around the Corner a show created and presented by [[Paddy Crosbie]], produced by [[James Plunkett]] .Your Dinner's Poured Out! by Paddy Crosbie. 1st Published 1981 O'Brien Press Ltd. It was renamed ''RTÃ Television'' in 1966, upon the renaming of the Radio Ãireann Authority to RTÃ, and became ''RTE1'' upon the launch of [[RTÃ Two|RTÃ2]] in 1978.{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/laweb/brc/brc_1970s.html|title=RTÃ LAUNCHES SECOND TELEVISION CHANNEL: 2 NOVEMBER 1978|publisher=RTÃ Archives|accessdate=24 April 2010}} Originally the station broadcast in black and white using the [[405-line television system]] in the North and East of the country but also across the country using the preferred European standard 625-line,{{cite web|url=http://www.irish-tv.com/405.asp|title=405 Lines in Ireland (1961 - 1983)|publisher=Tech-tir|accessdate=24 April 2010}} but began 625-line [[PAL]] colour transmissions in 1968. The first Outside Broadcast made in colour for RTE Television was when Ireland hosted the Eurovision Song Contest in Dublin in 1971.{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/laweb/brc/brc_1970s.html|title=THE ADVENT OF COLOUR TELEVISION: 1971|publisher=RTÃ Archives|accessdate=24 April 2010}} The UK national broadcaster BBC provided RTÃ with an OB Unit which could broadcast in colour for the event. In 1972, the first studios in RTE's Donnybrook headquarters were equipped for colour, and this was followed by the news studios in 1974, drama studios in 1975 and finally Studio 1 (the largest Studio, hosting shows such as The Late Late Show) in 1976. RTÃ One was also the sole Irish TV channel until 1978, when [[RTÃ Two|RTÃ2]] (known as Network 2 between 1988 and 2004) was created. The Irish Language station [[TG4]] began in 1996 as TnaG.{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/laweb/brc/brc_1990s.html|title=TEILIFÃS NA GAEILGE GOES ON AIR : 31 OCTOBER 1996|publisher=RTÃ Archives|accessdate=24 April 2010}} Since 1998 RTÃ One also competes with [[TV3 Ireland|TV3]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tv3.ie/corporate.php|title=About TV3|publisher=The TV3 Group|accessdate=24 April 2010}} RTÃ One since it began broadcasting has competed with [[BBC One]] and [[UTV]] and in 1980s RTÃ began competing with other [[satellite television|satellite]] and [[cable television|cable]] channels that are widely available across Ireland through [[cable television|cable]] subscription services due to the high take up of cable TV for UK channels since the 1960s, and the continued roll out of [[MMDS]] and [[satellite television|satellite]] during the 1980s and 1990s. Unlike many other national broadcasters, RTÃ One was late to begin broadcasting in the mornings, and 24 hour transmission only began in the early 1990s. From 1961, RTÃ Television would only broadcast from 17:35 until around 23:30 during the Winter months. In 1975 this changed slightly with transmission starting at around 15:30 and concluding around midnight (00:00). In 1988 RTÃ One launched a schedule with a new news bulletin at 13:00. To this day RTÃ One still does not offer a "breakfast television" programme, content to let commercially run TV3 to broadcast ''[[Ireland AM]]'' since 1999. RTÃ One instead shows repeats of different home produced shows such as ''[[The Afternoon Show]]'', and imports such as ''[[Are You Being Served?]]'', ''[[Neighbours]]'', ''[[Dallas]]'' etc. [[Euronews]] provides RTÃ One viewers with early morning news coverage, with RTÃ One's first news bulletin of the day airing at around 10:00am. However during the Olympics and special breaking news or election coverage, RTÃ One would provide a special bulletin in the morning. ===RTÃ One +1=== A [[timeshift channel]] for RTÃ One (RTÃ One +1) was launched on 27 May 2011{{cite web|author=Thursday, May 26, 2011 - 07:47 AM |url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/ireland/free-to-air-digital-television-service-to-be-launched-today-506470.html |title=Free-to-air digital television service to be launched today |publisher=Irish Examiner |date=2011-05-26 |accessdate=2011-09-19}} and shares channel space with [[RTÃjr]].{{cite web|author=Saorview |url=http://www.saorview.ie/channels-services/television-channels-and-services/ |title=Television Channels and Services | SAORVIEW |publisher=Saorview.ie |date=2011-03-03 |accessdate=2011-09-19}} The channel is available on [[Saorview]]. It was referred to as RTÃ One Deferred in the Easy TV commercial [[Digital terrestrial television|DTT]] multiplex application, Easy TV was made up of RTÃ NL and [[UPC Ireland]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bci.ie/DTT/easy_tv/easy_app.pdf |title=Guide to Submissions for DTT Multiplex Contracts |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2011-09-19}} RTÃ had also plans to create a third channel called RTÃ Three along with RTÃ One Deferred as reported in the Sunday Business Post in May 2008.{{cite web|url=http://archives.tcm.ie/businesspost/2008/05/18/story32957.asp|title=RTE aims to launch new channel|publisher=[[The Irish Post]]|date=2008-05-18}} RTÃ Three was dropped for the alternative RTÃ Plus/[[RTÃjr]]. RTÃ Plus would have initially been a time shift channel for RTÃ One's prime time schedule, starting each night at 7pm after RTÃjr ends for the night. This "Phase 1" of RTÃ plus will begin broadcasting in May 2011. "Phase 2" of RTÃ Plus was to be made up of an entirely different schedule to that of RTÃ One, RTÃ had hoped that this would be made available in May 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.dcenr.gov.ie/NR/rdonlyres/C13536EC-C703-4110-9A07-2A5DB4107DE3/0/PVTConsultationDocument.pdf|title=PVT Consultation Document|publisher=Department of Communications, Energy and Natural Resources (Ireland)|pages=10â11|accessdate=7 December 2010}} Minister Pat Carey gave the go ahead for RTÃ One +1 for a maximum of 4 years at which point it will be reviewed. He did not give permission for the second phase in the channel as he was advised by the BAI that it may cause problems for commercial service providers such as TV3. ==Budget== In 2008 RTÃ One received â¬58.44 from each license fee or 40.9% of the total â¬160 licence fee from the public. This is equal to â¬81,992,000 in total from the licence fee. RTÃ One spent in total â¬147,999,000 on Indigenous programming, of that a total â¬93,454,000 was produced by RTÃ internally (In-house productions), and â¬54,545,000 was produced by independent producers of which 50% is a requirement under Irish law. RTÃ spends a total of â¬13 million on International productions and a further â¬378,000 on non-RTÃ Irish produced shows for RTÃ One. â¬106,496,000 was received by RTÃ in advertising revenue from RTÃ One. RTÃ One had a net [[Economic surplus|surplus]] of â¬3,842,000 in 2008, however [[RTÃ]] [[breakeven|broke even]] in 2008. Other costs included Network transmission and other broadcasting operation costs which amounted to â¬31,387,000 in 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/about/pdfs/annual_report_2008_eng.pdf |title=15040_RTE_AR08_v6.2_FSÂ·.indd |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2011-09-19}} The table below outlines RTÃ One's total in-house and commissioned programming by genre in 2008:- {| border="0" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="1" style="width:50%; border:1px solid #aaa;" |- ! style="width:33%; background:silver;"|Genre ! style="width:33%; background:silver;"|Budget |- style="text-align:center; background:#a4f49e;" ||''[[Arts]]'' ||â¬1,081,000 |- style="text-align:center; background:#a4f49e;" ||''[[Education]]'' ||â¬833,000 |- style="text-align:center; background:#a4f49e;" ||''[[Religious]]'' ||â¬4,199,000 |- style="text-align:center; background:#a4f49e;" ||Other Factual ||â¬36,838,000 |- align=center ||Total Factual ||â¬42,951,000 |- style="text-align:center; background:#a4f49e;" || ''[[Drama]]'' || â¬38,776,000 |- style="text-align:center; background:#a4f49e;" ||''[[Entertainment]]'' ||â¬23,918,000 |- style="text-align:center; background:#a4f49e;" ||''[[Music]]'' ||â¬2,215,000 |- style="text-align:center; background:#a4f49e;" ||''[[News]]'',Current Affairs and ''[[Weather]]'' ||â¬38,834,000 |- style="text-align:center; background:#a4f49e;" ||''[[Sport]]'' ||â¬1,305,000 |- align=center ||''Total'' ||â¬147,999,000 |} ==Programming== RTÃ One airs a variety of programmes each week, both homegrown programming and imported programming. A typical week of programming on RTÃ One would be as follows: On Sunday they would air repeats of old American sitcoms such as ''[[The Cosby Show]]'', A Sunday Service is aired every Sunday morning around 11:00. Farming weather is aired, a host of cookery and lifestyle programmes are also shown. RTÃ One's Sunday night primetime line up usually consists of one of RTÃ's flagship talent shows such as ''[[The All Ireland Talent Show]]'' or ''[[Fame: The Musical|Fame]]''. The long running soap opera Fair City is shown Sunday nights. The weekday schedule consists of repeats of soaps and old sitcoms and/or dramas, every weekday from 16:00 to 18:00, RTÃ One air two daytime chat and lifestyle shows, Four Live hosted by Maura Deranne, and the Daily Show hosted by DÃ¡ithÃ­ O'SheÃ¡ and Claire Byrne. Weekday Primetime usually consists of Soaps such as EastEnders and Fair City and various lifestyle programmes, and current affairs programming airs after 21:00. On Friday night RTÃ One airs their flagship and longest running Chat Show in the world, The Late Late Show. RTÃ One also air a host of films throughout the week including the midweek movie on Wednesday at 21:30 and the big big movie (usually a children's film) Saturdays at 18:30. RTÃ One also air news coverage throughout the week including a 13:00, 18:00, and 21:00 news broadcast every day. ===News and current affairs=== {{main|RTÃ News and Current Affairs}} ''RTÃ News and Current Affairs'' provides all of RTÃ ONE's News and Current Affairs Programming. RTÃ News and current affairs television programmes include: ''News programming'' {| | *''[[RTÃ News: One O'Clock]]'' *''[[RTÃ News: Six One]]'' *''[[RTÃ News: Nine O'Clock]]'' | *''[[RTÃ News: Headlines]]'' *''[[Nuacht RTÃ]]'' *''[[RTÃ News with Signing]]'' | *''[[RTÃ News on Two]]'' |} ''Current Affairs Programming'' {| *''[[Prime Time]]'' *''[[Prime Time#...Investigates|Prime Time Investigates]]'' *''[[The Frontline (TV series)|The Frontline]]'' | *''[[The Week in Politics]]'' *''[[Nationwide (television)|Nationwide]]'' *''[[Capital D]]'' | *''[[Pobal]]'' *''[[One to One (TV series)|One To One]]'' *''[[Oireachtas Report]]'' | *''[[Euro Report]]'' |} RTÃ News and Current Affairs coverage of all major political events such as General Elections, Budgets, Local and European Elections and Referendums. Since 2000 RTÃ has covered the US Presidential Elections live. It also covers major political stories from the Northern Irish Assembly, including elections. ===Diversity=== RTÃ as a public service broadcaster is committed to providing awareness about the diverse communities found within the [[Republic of Ireland]]. RTÃ aims to providing access to different groups through different mediums. RTÃ Diversity provides awareness of Ireland's multicultural society. From 2002, RTÃ produced a weekly multicultural show called '''Mono'''.{{cite web|url=http://www.kairoscomms.ie/production.html |title=Kairos Communications Ltd - Production |publisher=Kairoscomms.ie |date= |accessdate=2011-09-19}} The show aired between 2002â2005 and had a similar format as Nationwide; but focused more on multicultural issues and had reports from all parts of the country. The show was produced by Kairos Communications for RTÃ and was presented by Shalini Sinha. RTÃ Diversity commissions a monthly show for individuals with [[Hard of hearing|hearing impairments or deafness]]. ''[[Hands On (TV series)|Hands On]]'' (originally called ''Sign of the Times'') airs every Sunday morning. The show is presented using [[Irish Sign Language]]. The show is also subtitled using Irish or English subtitles. In 2009, the number of ''Hands On'' programmes were reduced by 60%, from 20 to 7.{{cite web|author=Autumn escapes |url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/rte-cuts-funding-for-deaf-services--by-60pc-1850957.html |title=RTE cuts funding for deaf services by 60pc - National News, Frontpage |publisher=Independent.ie |date= |accessdate=2011-09-19}} Diversity has also been showcased on RTÃ Dramas: [[The Riordans]] and [[Glenroe]] featured several characters from the Irish Travelling Community. [[Fair City]] and [[The Clinic (TV series)|The Clinic]] have showcased a broader range of diversity which includes members of the [[Romani people|Roma community]], [[LGBT]] movement, African heritage, Eastern Europe and other ethnic minorities groups in Ireland. In April 2010, RTÃ revealed a new multicultural programme which will air from March 2011. The show has a budget of 45,000â¬ per episode.{{cite web|url=http://www.iftn.ie/?act1=record&only=1&aid=73&rid=4282956&tpl=archnewshome&force=1 |title=RTÃ Diversity Announces Multicultural Deadline | The Irish Film & Television Network |publisher=Iftn.ie |date=2010-04-01 |accessdate=2011-09-19}} ====ClÃ¡racha Gaelige==== In 1967 RTÃ produced a number of Irish programmes to help people learn the Irish Language, ''[[BuntÃºs Cainte]]'' was presented by MÃ¡ire OâNeill and Aileen Geoghegan.{{cite web |url=http://www.scoilnet.ie/lookathistory/Video2.aspx?FolderId=2&Id=545&ref=2 |title=BuntÃºs Cainte: Learning the Irish Language: 1967 |publisher=Scoilnet: Portal for Irish Education |accessdate=2009-08-03}} In the early 1990s they co-produced a similar show with [[BBC Northern Ireland]] called ''[[Now You're Talking]]'' it was based around the Ulster Dialect of Irish. In they early 2000s they produced a new series called Turas Teanga presented by newsreader [[Sharon NÃ­ BheolÃ¡in]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/tv/turasteanga/presenter.html |title=Turas Teanga |publisher=Rte.ie |date= |accessdate=2011-09-19}} During [[Seachtain na Gaeilge]] (Irish Language Week) continuity is provided through the Irish Language. During this week they also have a range of shows that promote the learning or use of the Irish language. In 2010 they produced An CÃ³r with Fiachna O BraonÃ¡in.{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/seachtainnagaeilge/index_eng.html |title=RTÃ |publisher=Rte.ie |date=1950-03-10 |accessdate=2011-09-19}} RTÃ also produce the highly successful Irish Language documentary strands [[LeargÃ¡s]], [[ScannÃ¡l]] and [[CSÃ]] (These are first shown on RTÃ One with repeats on [[TG4]]). [[Nuacht RTÃ]] provides around up of the days events at 17:40 each weekday. ====Education==== In the early years of TeilifÃ­s Ãireann most of the educational shows were aimed at children such as ''[[DÃ¡ithÃ­ Lacha]]''. In more recent years they have produced literacy programmes for adults such as ''[[NALA|Read, Write, Now]]'' presented by [[Derek Mooney]].{{cite web|url=http://www.readwritenow.ie/home.cfm |title=Read Write Now - Welcome to Read Write Now |publisher=Readwritenow.ie |date= |accessdate=2011-09-19}} ===Regional=== [[Nationwide (Irish TV series)|Nationwide]] is RTÃ's main regional programme, in 2010 Gala began sponsoring the show. The shows average audience for 2009 was 400,000 viewers.{{cite web|url=http://www.gala.ie/template1.php?page=advertising|title=Gala goes Nationwide|publisher=Gala Press Office|accessdate=24 April 2010}} The show began airing in the early 1990s.{{cite web|author=Alan Farquharson |url=http://indigo.ie/~alanf/cv.html |title=Alan Farquharson - Curriculum Vitae |publisher=Indigo.ie |date= |accessdate=2011-09-19}} In 1999 RTÃ tested opt out for Dublin, Cork and Galway on UHF signals, however Chorus (a Dublin cable operator at the time) aired the Galway edition, while NTL (the other Dublin cable operator aired the Dublin version).{{cite web|url=http://iolfree.ie/~icdg/local_rte.htm |title=RTE Local TV |publisher=Iolfree.ie |date= |accessdate=2011-09-19}} RTÃ do not provide local opt-out or regional news. However RTÃ Cork produces a number of other Irish shows. ''Capital D'' is the main show for Dublin, presented by Anne Cassin, it is broadcast Nationwide, it takes a look at issues in Dublin, while ''Ear to the Ground'' is a farming magazine show. Both ''Nationwide'' and ''Capital D'' are produced by RTÃ News and Current Affairs while ''Ear to the Ground'' is produced by Independent Films for RTÃ. ''Pobal'' is also a regional show focusing on news items from around the country it is produced by Nuacht RTÃ and Nuacht TG4. ===Drama=== ====1960s==== In 1961 as TeilifÃ­s Ãireann got ready to begin broadcasting it appointed [[Hilton Edwards]] as head of Drama, he was heavily involved in Irish theatre at the time. At this early stage they produced many international and local plays for television audiences such as ''[[Antigone]], [[The Wild Duck]], [[The Fire Raisers (play)|The Fire Raisers]], [[The Government Inspector]], [[The Physicists]], [[Martine (play)|Martine]], [[The Well of the Saints]], [[Candida (play)|Candida]], [[The Man of Destiny]], [[In the Shadow of the Glen]], [[Church Street (play)|Church Street]], [[The Field]], [[The Plough and the Stars]], [[The Shadow of a Gunman]]'' and ''[[The Hostage (play)|The Hostage]]''. Both of Edwards' successors Jim Fitzgerald and Chloe Gibson would continue with stage play adaptations but would also look for original dramas for television. [[Hugh Leonard]] adapted [[James Joyce]]'s ''[[Dubliners]]'' under the title Dublin and in 1966 he wrote ''[[Insurrection]]'' an 8 part real-time series which depicted the events of the [[1916 Easter Rising]] which was broadcast on Easter Week on the 50th anniversary of the rising, it was RTÃ biggest drama production of the 1960s, involving on location filming and the Army. In its first ten years on the air RTÃ produced 103 plays of which 66% were Irish and 50% began life as stage plays. Half of the drama produced came from serials such as the [[Dublin]] based urban soap ''[[Tolka Row]]'' which began broadcasting in 1964 and finished in 1968. In terms of population RTÃ was one of Europe's biggest producers of television drama.{{cite web|url=http://webpages.dcu.ie/~sheehanh/60s-itvd.htm|title=Chapter 4: The 1960s: The Coming Of Television|last=Sheehan, Dr. H,|year=2001|accessdate=11 May 2010}} In 1965 ''[[The Riordans]]'' began broadcasting, this would begin the [[Wesley Burrowes]] trilogy of Irish Agrisoaps (Agricultural based dramas), it was followed by ''[[Bracken]]'' in 1978 (and was aired on RTÃ One) as [[Gabriel Byrne]]'s character (Pat Barry) moved from [[Kilkenny]] to [[Wicklow]] and in 1982 two of ''[[Bracken]]'''s main characters Dinny and Milie Byrne moved to [[Glenroe]] which ran until 2001. ====1970s==== In the 1970s RTÃ produced several urban dramas set outside Dublin. ''Southside'' was based in a suburb of Cork City, its second series was renamed ''Newpark Southside'' and took on a more comic tone to the original serious social tone, while retaining underlying social stories. The series was created by David Hayes. ''The Burke Enginma'' began in 1975 and was RTÃ's first [[police procedural]] something that they did not return to very often. ''Partners In Practice'' was RTÃ's first medical drama and was loosely based on successful TV formats from aboard such as ''Emergency Ward 10'', ''Dr. Finlay's Casebook'', ''Marcus Welby M.D.'' and ''Dr. Kildare''. ''Partners in Practice'' was set in the new sprawling suburban Dublin in the fictional town of Sallybawn. Sallybawn was based on the new 1970s sprawling developments such as Tallaght. The series was set in the fictional Sallybawn Health Centre. It ran for one season in 1972 and was written by [[Carolyn Swift]]. In 1978 Louis Lentin became head of RTÃ Drama. He started ''Thursday Playdate'', these were once of plays which dramatized current events and current affairs in Ireland. He would also be responsible for ''The Spike'' a controversial drama that was to run for 10 weeks only to be taken of the after the fifth episode. Problems surrounded both the content (A very critical look at the VEC system in Irish Education) and poor scriptwritting to deal with major issues.{{cite web|url=http://webpages.dcu.ie/~sheehanh/70s-itvd.htm|title=Chapter 5: The 1970s: Progress, Pressures and Protests|last=Sheehan, Dr. H,|year=2001|publisher=DCU|accessdate=11 May 2010}} ====1980s==== RTÃ One had a major success with 1980s ''[[Strumpet City]]'' based on the novel by [[James Plunkett]] about the 1913 [[Dublin Lockout]]. It was successfully sold around the world to various countries including the [[USSR]]. ''The Year of The French'' was a major follow up period drama with twice the production budget as ''Strumpet City'', however it was not as successful. ''The Year of The French'' was one of the many co-productions that RTÃ produced during the 1980s, it was co-produced with the UK's [[Channel 4]] and France's [[France 2|FR2]]. Also in the 1980s they co-produced ''[[The Irish R.M.]]'' and ''[[Echoes (TV series)|Echoes]]'' with [[Channel 4]] the newly established UK public service broadcaster. In the mid-1980s RTÃ developed a sit-com called ''Leave it to Mrs. O'Brien'' which centered around the housekeeper of a Parish Priest. It is often quoted as one of the comedies which shows that RTÃ cannot produce good comedy. The series was a critical and audience failure. RTÃ would not produce another sit-com until the mid-1990s, while being criticized for not commissioning another series that featured a Parish Priest Housekeeper. In 1989, RTÃ returned with a new drama series based in [[Dublin city]] called ''[[Fair City]]''. In 2010, the show has celebrated its 20th anniversary since it first broadcast. The show continues to air four nights a week on RTÃ One. ====1990s==== In 1993, RTÃ One began to broadcast [[TG4]]'s soap ''[[Ros na RÃºn]]''. The show initially broadcast for a short season each year. The show no-longer airs on RTÃ One, but instead airs each night on TG4. The show is also airs on television in Scotland and America. In 1994 RTÃ broadcast ''[[Family (1994)|Family]]'' by [[Roddy Doyle]], a co-production with the [[BBC]]. In the mid-1990s RTÃ return to sit-com with the development of ''Upwardly Mobile'' which ran for 3 season. The series was a critical failure but it often land in RTÃ top programmes each week. At the same time [[Channel 4]] commissioned ''[[Father Ted]]'', which RTÃ is often incorrectly accused of turning down. RTÃ would not return to sit-coms until 2001 when ''The Cassidys'' appeared on ''[[RTÃ Two]]'' this was also a failure however two other successive comedies appeared in the same year on [[RTÃ Two]], ''[[Bachelors Walk]]'' and ''[[Paths to Freedom]]''. In the late 1990s RTÃ co-produced many period dramas based on novels by significant modern day Irish novelist such as ''[[Falling for a Dancer]]'' and ''[[Amongst Women]]''. They all produced the [[police procedural]] ''Making the Cut'' and its spin off series ''[[DDU: District Detective Unit|DDU]]''. ====2000s==== As a replacement for the axed rural soap ''Glenroe'' RTÃ commissioned ''On Home Ground'', surrounding a rural [[Gaelic Athletic Association|GAA]] club.http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0289005/ The series was not well received and was replaced in 2003 by ''[[The Clinic (TV series)|The Clinic]]''. The Clinic was an award-winning primetime television medical drama series produced by Parallel Film Productions for RTÃ. The show ran for seven seasons between September 2003 to November 2009. The last ever episode aired on RTÃ One on Sunday, 15 November 2009. The show was so successful that it also aired in Finland, New Zealand, [[Iceland]], Scotland and Portugal. Since 2000 RTÃ has increased its output of specialized dramas. These drama's have discussed a broad range of issues such as the Irish Hepatitis C scandal in ''[[No Tears (TV serial)|No Tears]]'' (2002){{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/tv/theview/archive/20020115.html |title=RTÃ Television - The View |publisher=Rte.ie |date= |accessdate=2011-09-19}} which featured Academy Award Winner [[Brenda Fricker]]. In 2004 RTÃ co-produced with Denmark's [[TV 2 (Denmark)|TV2]] a gritty drama series based on criminality in Dublin City. ''[[Proof (TV series)|Proof]]'' aired for two seasons and starred [[Orla Brady]]. In 2006 RTÃ broadcasted a fictional drama based on a nuclear fallout called ''[[Fallout (RTÃ drama)|Fallout]]''. Following this another drama appeared on RTÃ One in September 2006, the [[docudrama]] about the ''Stardust'' disaster, entitled ''[[Stardust (TV miniseries)|Stardust]]'', to mark the 25th anniversary of the incident. In 2007, RTÃ began the drama series''[[Single-Handed (2007 drama)|Single-Handed]]''. Three episodes of the series ran over the course of three years when ITV bought the rights to the show in 2009, which lead to the co-production of the 4th series with [[ITV]]. In 2007, RTÃ aired ''[[Damage (television film)|Damage]]'' a drama which focused on rape and sexual abuse. In 2008, RTÃ produced ''[[Whistleblower (TV series)|Whistleblower]]'' this drama highlighted irregular obstetric practices within Irish hospitals. Another drama in 2008 included ''[[Bitter Sweet (TV drama)|Bitter Sweet]]''. This drama follows the difficulties encountered by three female friends who undergo difficult changes to their respective lives. In June 2009 RTÃ broadcast ''[[Father & Son (TV serial)|Father & Son]]'' co-produced with [[ITV]]. ====2010s==== In 2010 their drama series ''[[Raw (TV series)|Raw]]'' moved from [[RTÃ Two]] to RTÃ One, 3rd series of ''[[Raw (TV series)|Raw]]'' remained on RTÃ One in 2011 and the 4th season was announced in August 2011. A 5th series of ''Single-Handed'' has not been announced, however reports suggest that RTÃ and ITV are still negotiation the next series. The drama surrounding the Irish banking crisis has yet to be announced.{{cite web|url=http://www.tribune.ie/business/news/article/2010/feb/07/new-four-part-rte-drama-to-document-the-banking-cr/|title=New four-part RTE drama to document the banking crisis|last=Quinn|first=Eamon|date=7 February 2010|publisher=The Sunday Tribune|accessdate=13 June 2010}} The series ''[[Love/Hate (TV series)|Love/Hate]]'' (starring [[Aidan Gillen]]) detailing the lives of the Dublin's criminal underworld began in 2010 with a second series announced in August 2011. The 2010 [[Live-Aid]] biopic''When Harvey met Bobby'' (surrounding the relationship between [[Bob Geldof]] and [[Harvey Goldsmith]]) was co-produced with the [[BBC]]. ''[[Wild Decembers]]'' based on the novel by Edna O'Brien aired at Christmas 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/ten/2010/0712/rte.html|title=New Irish TV dramas coming to RTÃ|date=12 July 2010|publisher=RTÃ.ie|accessdate=12 July 2010}} A new drama surrounding the disappearance of a young girl has begun production, titled ''Amber''. It is directed by [[Thaddeus OâSullivan]] and will star [[Eva Birthistle]] and [[David Murray (actor)|David Murray]].{{cite web|url=http://www.iftn.ie/news/?act1=record&only=1&aid=73&rid=4284194&tpl=archnews&force=1|title=Eva Birthistle & David Murray Join RTÃ Drama 'Amber', Thaddeus OâSullivan to direct|date=24 August 2010|publisher=iftn.ie|accessdate=25 August 2011}} ===Entertainment=== ====Chat shows==== *'''''The Late Late Show (1961 to present)''''' RTÃ One is home to the world's longest running [[chat show]], [[The Late Late Show]]. It began broadcasting in 1961 and was presented for over 30 years by [[Gay Byrne]]. In September 1999, [[Pat Kenny]] took over the role and after hosting nine seasons as Late Late host he stepped down to host a new political programme. In September 2009, [[Ryan Tubridy]] took over as host. *''Saturday Live'' and ''Kenny Live! (1980s and 1990s)'' Before hosting [[The Late Late Show]] Pat Kenny hosted a weekly chat show ''[[Saturday Live (Irish TV series)|Saturday Live]]''. He went on to host the show permanently and its title was changed to ''[[Kenny Live]]!''. *'''Limelight (1990s)''' [[Carrie Crowley]] hosted a talk show during the summer months for two seasons. The show aired every Saturday night at 21:30 between June and August. *'''''Tubridy Tonight (2004â2009)''''' [[Ryan Tubridy]] hosted his own Saturday night chat show between 2004 and 2009. He would later go onto to host The Late Late Show from September 2009. *'''''Saturday Night with Miriam (2005âPresent)''''' ''[[Saturday Night with Miriam]]'' is hosted by [[Miriam O'Callaghan]] and airs during summer months on RTÃ One when programmes such as ''[[The Late Late Show]]'' is off air. The show is well known for its wide variety of guests, which often include musicians, who usually perform on the show. [[The Duckworth Lewis Method]] made their television debut on ''Saturday Night with Miriam'' in 2009's season opener.{{cite web|url=http://www.hotpress.com/news/5543805.html|title=The Duckworth Lewis Method make live debut|date=2009-06-18|accessdate=2009-06-18|publisher=''[[Hot Press]]''}} *'''''The Saturday Night Show (2010)''''' In January 2010, RTÃ produced a new chat show hosted by [[Brendan O'Connor (journalist)|Brendan O'Connor]] called ''[[The Saturday Night Show]]'' it has been given an initial run of 8 weeks. RTÃ revealed it will not be renewing the show. *'''''Tonight with Craig Doyle (2010)''''' [[Craig Doyle]] has also been given his own chat show.{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/about/pressreleases/2010/0125/tvnewprogramming250110.html |title=About RTÃ: RTÃ Announces More New Programming to Brighten our way into Spring |publisher=Rte.ie |date=2010-01-25 |accessdate=2011-09-19}} This show will replace [[The Saturday Night Show]]. Both of these shows are aimed to replace the highly successful ''Tubridy Tonight'' which ended in 2009. Tonight with Craig Doyle will begin on RTE One from 18 April 2010.{{cite web|url=http://tvsales.rte.ie/sponsorship/sponsorshipopportunities.htm#prog10 |title=RTÃ Media Sales - Television |publisher=Tvsales.rte.ie |date= |accessdate=2011-09-19}} *'''''For One Night Only (2011)''''' A show where Gay Byrne Chats with Irish Musicians,also the musicians sing some of their songs ====Game shows/quiz shows==== In the 1960s and 1970s RTÃ ran the ''[[Quicksilver (Irish TV show)|Quicksilver]]'' quiz show presented by [[Bunny Carr]]. The show would tour the country and visit different towns. The contestants were picked at random to answer the questions, due to this random selection process the show is fondly remembered for questions such as "What the term for a male [[bee]]?" and the answer "a [[wasp]]?". It also coined an Irish phrase "stop the lights", usually stated when something is surprising. In the 1980s RTÃ produced game shows like ''Play the Game'', and Gerry Ryan's ''Secrets'' and quiz shows "Murphy's Micro-Quiz-M" (hosted by Mike Murphy), ''Where in the World?'' (hosted by Theresa Lowe), ''[[Rapid Roulette]]'' (hosted by Maxi) and ''[[Know Your Sport]]'' (hosted by George Hamilton). Since 1989 RTÃ have produced a game show with the Irish National Lottery. [[Winning Streak]] was the first such show originally hosted by [[Mike Murphy (broadcaster)|Mike Murphy]], who had had previous success with his chat show ''The Live Mike'' and the Irish version of ''[[Candid Camera]]''. He had also present ''Mike's Micro Quiz'' a family quiz show that included a "hi-tech" games machine. Winning Steak started of as a half hour show on Friday nights in the late 1980s and by the mid-1990 was an hour long Saturday night game show. In the mid-1990s ''Winning Streak'' was joined by other National Lottery game shows including ''Millionaire'' and ''Fame and Fortune'' hosted by Marty Whelan, ''[[Telly Bingo]]'' hosted by [[Liz Bonnin]]. In the 1990s RTÃ had international success with ''[[The Lyrics Board]]'', while it was derided by the critics the format was sold in many European countries. The show was originally presented by [[Aonghus McAnally]] during its initially run and in the 2000s by [[Linda Martin]]. Quiz shows included ''Challenging Times'' (hosted by Kevin Myres) and ''Dodge The Question'' (hosted by [[Jonathan Philbin Bowman]]). The 1990s saw RTÃ's verision of ''Talkabout'' hosted by Ian Dempsey and later by Alan Hughes. After Gay Byrne's decision to leave The Late Late Show, he was brought back by the station to host the Irish version of ''[[Who Wants to be a Millionaire]]'' however after two seasons the show was drop as RTÃ were unable to find a sponsor after [[Vodafone]] [[Eircell]] pull its sponsorship, the producers (Tyrone Productions) and RTÃ were in discussions with the National Lottery for a scratch card version of the show, ironically the National Lottery had defended the use of the term Millionaire a number of years previously due to its scratch card and TV game show ''Millionaire'' hosted by Marty Whelan for RTÃ. RTÃ One broadcast two editions of the Irish version of ''[[Test the Nation]]'' presented by [[Miriam O'Callaghan]] in 2006 and 2007. ====Music==== *RTÃ One has shown many Irish traditional music shows including ''[[The Pure Drop]]'' and ''[[Come West Along The Road]]''. *''Number 1'' was a pop music quiz show from the 1980s and they also aired [[Top of the Pops]]. *During the 1980s they had several live music shows with famous Irish stars of the time including ''The [[Sandy Kelly]] Show''. *In the late 1980s and early 1990s [[Marty Whelan]] hosted a popular talent search called ''GFI: Go For It''. In the mid-1990s RTÃ co-produced a talent series with BBC Northern Ireland called ''Let Me Entertain You'' hosted by [[Gerry Ryan]], a 16 year old [[Samantha Mumba]] was one of the finalists. *RTÃ One has also several documentaries about Irish Country Music and the Showband era entitled ''A Little Bit Country/Showband'', hosted and produced by Shay Healey. In 2009 they broadcast ''All Ireland Choir Competition 2009''. ====Reality TV==== Since the start of the 2000s RTÃ have produced several Reality TV programmes for RTÃ One. In 2001, RTÃ One broadcast the successful [[Popstars]] format to find Ireland's next top pop band. The eventual winners were the band members of [[Six (band)]], including on [[Nadine Coyle]] however due to her age at the time she had to be drop from the band, she went on to appear in [[Popstars: The Rivals]] on [[ITV1]] and through that became a member of the girl band [[Girls Aloud]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/tv/scannal/nadine.html|title=Sweet Little Lies|publisher=RTÃ|accessdate=17 June 2010}} Due to the success in the Popstars format RTÃ set about looking for a new series for 2002, ''[[You're A Star]]'' was a similar show to ''[[American Idol]]'' and ''[[The X Factor (UK)|X-Factor]]'' running from 2002 to 2008, during which they select acts to go to the [[Eurovision]] song contest.{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/tv/star/|title=You're A Star|publisher=RTÃ|accessdate=17 June 2010}} In 2008 it was replaced by the ''[[All Ireland Talent Show]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.herald.ie/entertainment/tv-radio/rtes-allireland-talent-show-is-a-ratings-winner-1593335.html|title=RTE's All-Ireland Talent Show is a ratings winner|date=6 January 2009|publisher=Evening Herald|accessdate=17 June 2010}} In 2010 they broadcast ''[[Fame: The Musical]]'' a reality TV talent search for stars of the stage version of the highly successful film and TV series ''[[Fame (1980 film)|Fame]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.herald.ie/entertainment/tv-radio/tears-and-a-sad-farewell-to-fame-2219931.html|title=Tears and a sad farewell to fame|last=Byrne|date=14 June 2010|publisher=Evening Herald|accessdate=17 June 2010}} Other reality shows include 2 seasons (2001 and 2002) of ''[[Treasure Island (show)|Treasure Island]]'' similar in format to ''[[Survivor (U.S. TV series)|Survivor]]''. Senator Mark Daly appear in the second series coming 3rd overall.{{cite web|url=http://www.senatormarkdaly.com/site/index.php/tv-rte-treasure-island-2002|title=RTÃ voices concerns on Cabin Fever report|last=Mark|first=Daly|publisher=http://www.senatormarkdaly.com|accessdate=17 June 2010}} ''[[Cabin Fever (TV series)|Cabin Fever]]'' (2003) which had a group of people set sail around the Irish coast, this caused controversy when the ship ran aground half way through the series.{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2005/0324/cabinfever.html|title=RTÃ voices concerns on Cabin Fever report|last=Tom|first=MacSweeney|date=24 March 2010|publisher=RTÃ|accessdate=17 June 2010}} RTÃ One has also produce [[celebrity]] versions of their reality TV shows. ''[[Charity You're A Star]]'', ''[[Celebrity Farm]]'' and ''[[FÃ¡ilte Towers]]'' have all gained respectable audiences but critics have been less than impressed. RTÃ's most successful celebrity reality TV is ''[[The Restaurant (Irish TV series)|The Restaurant]]''. ===Factual=== ''[[Garda Patrol]]'' ran for a number of years on RTÃ One. It was a fifteen minute weekly show asking for help with crimes from the public. In the early 1990s RTÃ revamped the show as a monthly hour long show called ''Crime Line'', hosted by [[David Harvey (television)|David Harvey]] and [[Marian Finucane]]{{cite web|url=http://www.radiowaves.fm/newsstand/irishindependent/050620.shtml|title=Marian: How I nearly walked out on RTE|date=20 June 2005|publisher=Irish Independent|accessdate=13 June 2010}} (Towards the end of the series was hosted by [[Anne Doyle]]). In the mid-2000s RTÃ replaced CrimeLine with a similar show ''Crime Call''. ''Crime Call'' is presented by Anna Cassin and Con Murphy.{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/tv/crimecall/index.html|title=Crime Call|publisher=RTÃ|accessdate=13 June 2010}} * ''[[Radharc]]'' (an Irish term for view, vision, spectacle or sight) aired from the 1960s and the 1990s. They were documentaries filmed by [[Catholic]] priests. The series produced 400 documentaries which focused on some regional stories but mainly international stories about Catholic [[Missionaries]] around the world and world events. The series came about during the 1950s as public discussion centred around the new television services. The documentaries all took a religious angle on events.{{cite web|url=http://www.radharc.ie/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=14&Itemid=29|title=Our History|publisher=The Radharc Trust|accessdate=29 April 2010}} The Irish Film Institute(IFI) are the custodians of the Radharc documentaries.{{cite web|url=http://www.irishfilm.ie/archive/collections_documentaries.asp|title=Irish Film Archive: Collections: Documentaries|publisher=Irish Film Institute (IFI)|accessdate=29 April 2010}} *''[[To the Waters and the Wild]]'' *''[[Waterways]]'' *''[[Who Do You Think You Are? (Irish TV series)|Who Do You Think You Are?]]'' *''[[Blood of the irish|Blood of the Irish]]'' ====History==== * ''[[Reeling in the Years]]'' is one of RTÃ most popular history strands, it provides a history of Ireland from 1960 to 1999, it began as part of RTÃ Autumn 1999 schedule as Reeling in the Years 1980s. It was archive clips from Irish and international archives showing the big events of the world from an Irish perspective including 2 [[Eurovision]] wins, 3 Irish general elections in one year, the Recession, Migration, [[Delorean Motor Company]], [[GUBU]], [[Ronald Reagan]]'s visit to Ireland, All Ireland Championship wins etc. 1960 - 1969, 1970â1979 and 1990 - 1990 were all broadcast, events included the Dublin/Monaghan bombings, U2's first TV appearance, Slane Concerts, the axing of ''[[The Riordans]]'', [[Riverdance]], Miley and Fidelma's hay shed love in ''[[Glenroe]]'', ''Twin Peaks'' to more serious news such as the [[Omagh]] bombings, [[The Good Friday Agreement]], The resignation of the Minister for Foreign Affairs [[Ray Burke (Irish politician)|Ray Burke]] and the inauguration of president [[Mary Robinson]] etc. It is expected that the series will return for ''Reeling in the Years 2000s'' as part of RTÃ Television's 50th anniversary celebrations in 2011. *''True Lives'' *''Hidden Histories'' ====Arts==== *''[[Arts Lives]]'' is a series of arts documentaries produced by independent producers for RTÃ. They may also be co-funded by other broadcasters from around Europe. Some of the documentaries include: ''[[The Riordans]]: Tea, Taboos & Tractors'' about the successful rural soap opera, ''[[John O'Conor]]'s Beethoven Boot Camp'', ''[[Hugh Leonard]]: Odd Man In'', ''[[Patrick Collins (painter)|Patrick Collins]]: Through Sligo Eyes'', ''[[Graham Linehan]] - Funny Business'' and ''[[Ronnie Drew]] - September Song''.{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/tv/artslives/index.html |title=RTÃ Television - Arts Lives - About the Show |publisher=Rte.ie |date=2010-10-20 |accessdate=2011-09-19}} *''[[The View (Irish TV series)|The View]]'' is a weekly arts and cultural review programme broadcast each Tuesday night. It was original broadcast on RTÃ Two as ''[[Later On 2]]''. ===Young people's programmes=== {{main|The Den}}{{main|Two_Tube}} Up to 1988 the majority of RTÃ's children's programmes were aired on RTÃ One. In the early years these shows included [[DÃ¡ithÃ­ Lacha]] an Irish Language animated series about a duck. In the 1970s they produced ''[[Wanderly Wagon]]'' which was developed for RTÃ by [[Eugene Lambert]] and a spin off show in the 1980s called ''[[Fortycoats & Co.]]'' however Eugene Lambert is on the record as saying that he was not involved and that RTÃ just rehashed old ''Wanderly Wagon'' stories. The 1980s saw RTÃ's first Saturday morning children's strand called ''Anything Goes'', this was followed by ''Action Station Saturday'' and ''Pajo's Junkbox''. In the 1990s their Saturday mornings included ''Pajo's The Whole Shabang'' and ''Scratch Saturday'' which included ''The [[Fanta]] Roadshow Chart'' with Andy Ruane, various changes took place on Saturday mornings during the 1990s with the final RTÃ One children's morning strand coming from RTÃ Cork called ''The Swamp''. In the late 1990s all children's weekend programming was fully moved to [[RTÃ Two|Network 2]] with ''T/X'' and ''The Disney Club''. ''[[Dempsey's Den]]'' aired on the channel from 1986 to 1988, [[Zig and Zag (puppets)|Zig and Zag]] made their debuts on RTÃ One. Since 1988 the majority of RTÃ's children programming airs on its sister channel [[RTÃ Two]]. [[RTÃ Two]] provide different strands of programming tailored at different age groups these include: [[The Den|Den Tots]] (1-4 year olds), [[The Den]] (5-16 year olds), [[Two Tube|TwoTube]] (16 - 22 year olds). Every Saturday night RTÃ ONE at 18:30 airs '''The Big Big Movie''' this strand features movies which a tailored towards a family audience. ===Daytime=== In the early 1980s, RTÃ began testing daytime television for audiences on RTÃ One. This was a major commitment since [[RTÃ Two]] was failing to gain audience that it required. Their first daytime show was hosted by [[Thelma Mansfield]] - one of their regular continuity announcers - ''Good Afternoon'' was a mix of live interviews, music, children's television and soap operas.http://www.thelmamansfield.ie/images/press/VIP2_nov09.jpg In 1986, RTÃ debuted its new afternoon show which featured a mixture of daytime chat and children's television. In September the channel aired '''Live at 3''' broadcasting from 15:00 each weekday. This was followed by a new children's series [[The Den (television)|Dempsey's Den]].[http://tvlistings.thetvroomplus.com/listing-3735.html ]{{dead link|date=September 2011}} Live at 3 was presented by [[Derek Davis]] and Thelma Mansfield from 1986 to 1997. It included a broad range of topics (healthcare, cookery, DIY, fashion and culture). It was a major departure for the daytime schedule and in an interview with TV Now Derek Davis described how many other European broadcasters were travelling over to Ireland to visit this mix genre daytime TV chat show. In 1997 with the departure of Derek Davis, Live at 3 was merged with another TV series called ''12 to 1''. ''12 to 1'' was similar in style to ''Live at 3'' only it concentrated on Light chat with hosts [[Marty Whelan]] and Ciana Campbell. Ciana Campbell had prior to this tested out a live afternoon phone in show (called ''Over to You''), similar in format to RTÃ Radio's successfully [[Liveline]], this eventually led to ''12 to 1''.[http://tvlistings.thetvroomplus.com/listing-659.html ]{{dead link|date=September 2011}} In the late 1990s Marty Whelan, Ciana Campbell and Thelma Mansfield all remained as part of the daytime TV line-up and featured on ''PM Live''. In 1999, Thelma Mansfield retired from RTÃ to concentrate on her art career.http://www.thelmamansfield.ie/images/press/VIP_nov09.jpg This later led to the demise of ''PM Live'', which was replaced in September, 1999, with ''[[Open House (Ireland)|Open House]]''. ''Open House'' was the first time that RTÃ had an independent producer produce their daytime TV service. Tyrone Productions produced the show in the RTÃ studios and it was hosted by Mary Kennedy and Marty Whelan from 1999 to 2003. In 2003, RTÃ revamped their daytime schedule and axed ''Open House'' and replaced it with two new shows, ''[[The Afternoon Show]]'' and [[The Big Bite]]. The Big Bite was an unusual departure for RTÃ's daytime schedule as it had heavier content than previous shows which aired in this time-slot, it was hosted by economist [[David McWilliams]]. The Big Bite was replaced with ''[[Seoige and O'Shea]]'', which was also produced by Tyrone Productions. Joe O'Shea and Grainne Seoige presented the show together for 2 seasons until Joe O'Shea left in 2007, he was replaced by Grainne's sister SÃ­le Seoige and the show was rename Seoige. ''[[Seoige]]'' lasted one season and was replaced by an extended version of ''The Afternoon Show'' produced by Green Inc Productions for RTÃ. The Afternoon Show was first presented by [[Anna Nolan]], [[Blathnaid Ni Chofaigh]] and [[Sheana Keane]]. [[Anna Nolan]] left the show after a year to focus on more serious TV such as RTÃ's ''[[Would You Believe (TV series)|Would You Believe]]'' series of documentaries. Blathanid and Sheana both worked on the show together for a number of years until 2008 (when it was reported they had had a falling out{{cite web|url=http://www.herald.ie/entertainment/around-town/tension-high-as-sheana-and-blaithnaid-meet-1752243.html|title=Tension high as Sheana and Blaithnaid meet|last=Nolan|first=Laura|date=27 May 2009|publisher=The Evening Herald|accessdate=5 August 2010}}), various presenters stepping into either Blathanid's or Sheana's shoes, with the final series being presented by Sheana and [[Maura Derrane]] (former ''[[Ireland AM]]'' presenter). In 2010, RTÃ One revamped its afternoon schedule, which will debut in September 2010. RTÃ set about seeking tenders from independent producers, as a consequence of this process RTÃ axed ''The Afternoon Show''.{{cite web|url=http://www.iftn.ie/?act1=record&aid=73&rid=4282878&sr=1&only=1&hl=afternoon+show&tpl=archnews |title=RTÃ Reviews âAfternoon Showâ Slot | The Irish Film & Television Network |publisher=Iftn.ie |date= |accessdate=2011-09-19}} Two new afternoon shows will begin in September 2010 they are ''[[4 Live]]'' and ''[[The Daily Show (Irish TV series)|The Daily Show]]''. ''4 Live'' will be presented by Maura Derrane (former co-presenter of ''The Afternoon Show''), while ''The Daily Show'' will be presented by TG4 Weather Man [[DÃ¡ithÃ­ Ã SÃ©]] and former ''Ireland AM'' presenter [[Claire Byrne]]. Both shows will broadcast from 16:00 to 17:45 GMT.{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/ten/2010/0805/rtetelevision.html|title=RTÃ Television announces new season|date=5 August 2010|publisher=RTÃ TEN|accessdate=5 August 2010}} Both new daytime shows are produced by Green Inc. for RTÃ.{{cite web|url=http://www.iftn.ie/news/?act1=record&only=1&aid=73&rid=4283311&tpl=archnews&force=1|title=Green Inc Going 'Live' and 'Daily'|date=31 August 2010|publisher=IFTN.ie|accessdate=31 August 2010}} ===Lifestyle=== In the 1980s RTÃ One's lifestyle programming consisted of shows such as *''Check Up'' - A weekly health show *''Head 2 Toe'' - A weekly fashion series *''See Here'' - A weekly consumers show *''Family Matters'' - A weekly issue based show for parents, hosted by Eamon Lawlor and Caroline Murphy. Much of RTÃ's lifestyle output was produced in-house until the 1990s when Independent Producers began producing shows such as: - *''About the House'' - An Educational/Lifestyle show about home renovations *''Ear to the Ground'' - A weekly Agricultural magazine show *''Beyond The Hall Door'' - A studio based Interior design show by the 2000s it had left the studio to do up homes *''Bon Voyage'' - A travel show *''Darina Allen'' - A cookery Show Most of RTÃ's Lifestyle programming is air Monday to Friday between 19:00 and 21:00, and repeated on Saturday and Sunday mornings. Their current set of lifestyle programmes include ''About the House'', ''Showhouse'', ''Heat'' and ''Rachel Allen: Bakes''. ===Imported programming=== ====1961 - 1969==== RTÃ One has always relied on a certain amount of programming from abroad and they have also always been under pressure from UK TV channels to provide programming from other countries. The 1960s on RTÃ is characterized by American and British imports such as ''[[Annie Oakley (TV series)|Annie Oakley]]'', ''[[Everglades]]'', ''[[Have Gun Will Travel]]'', ''[[The Donna Reed Show]]'', ''[[The Adventures of Robin Hood (TV series)|The Adventures of Robin Hood]]'', ''[[Batman (TV series)|Batman]]'', ''[[The Man from U.N.C.L.E.]]'', ''[[The Andy Williams Show]]'', ''[[The Dick Van Dyke Show]]'', ''[[The Adventures of Robinson Crusoe (TV series)|Robinson Crusoe]]'', ''[[Lucy Show]]'', ''[[Dr Finlay's Casebook]]'', ''[[The World Around Us]]'', ''[[The World of Wooster]]'' and ''[[Sherlock Holmes]]''. Children's programming at this time consisted of such shows as ''[[The Road Runner Show]]'', ''[[The Flintstones]]'', ''[[Skippy the Bush Kangaroo|Skippy]] and ''[[Quick Draw McGraw]]''. In 1963 they also broadcast Italian lessons ''Parliamo Italiano''.{{cite web|url=http://tvlistings.thetvroomplus.com/?id=6:ca|title=RTÃ TV Listings 1960 - 1969|publisher=The TV Room|page=10|accessdate=24 April 2010}} ====1970 - 1979==== RTÃ began expanding its schedule during the 1970s with Educational and Children's programming being broadcast from 11am. Children's shows imported for the channel included ''[[Tarzan]]'', ''[[Modern Madcaps]]'', ''[[The Road Runner Show]]'', ''[[Land of the Giants]]'', ''[[Apple's Way]]'', ''[[Babar the Elephant#Films and television|Babar]]'', ''[[Noddy (character)|Noddy'']], ''[[Sesame Street]]'', ''[[Gemini Man]]'', ''[[Clue Club]]'' and ''[[Scooby-Doo]]'', while educational programming included ''Education: Zarabanda'', ''First Steps in First Aid'' and ''German Lesson'' other daytime shows included ''[[South Riding (TV series)|South Riding]]'', ''[[The Pallisers]]'' and ''[[Thrill Seekers]]''. Prime time imports included ''[[Lights Out (1946 TV series)|Lights Out]]'', ''The Spanish Farm'', ''[[The Brady Bunch]]'', ''[[Bridget Loves Bernie]]'', ''[[Fawlty Towers]]'', ''[[Little House on the Prairie (TV series)|Little House on the Prairie]]'',"The Waltons", "Poldark" ''[[The Muppet Show]]'', ''[[Anne of the Thousand Days]]'', ''Midnight Is a Place'', ''[[Are You Being Served?]]''.{{cite web|url=http://tvlistings.thetvroomplus.com/?id=6:ca|title=RTÃ TV Listings 1970 -1978 & RTÃ 1 TV Lisings 1978 - 1979|publisher=The TV Room|page=10|accessdate=24 April 2010}} In 1978 RTÃ One began broadcasting many UK TV show such as ITV's ''[[Sale of the Century]]'' and ''[[Match of the Day]]'' which was simulcast with the BBC. [[RTÃ Two]] began broadcasting on the 2 November 1978. ====1980 - 1989==== During the 1980s many of the language courses on during daytime hours moved to the weekend, children's was presented first as ''Good Afternoon'' with many Adult daytime shows mixed in, until 1986 when ''[[The Den (television)|Dempsey's Den]]'' started to broadcast, imports for Children included ''The World of Jules Verne'', ''[[Ludwig (cartoon)|Ludwig]]'', ''[[Yogi's Treasure Hunt]]'', ''[[Danger Bay]]'', ''[[Arthur and the Square Knights of the Round Table]]'', ''[[Supergran]]'', ''European Folk Tales'', ''[[Kaboodle]]'' and ''[[The Real Ghostbusters]]''. Other daytime shows included ''[[Upstairs Downstairs]]'' and ''[[Emmerdale Farm]]''. Prime time imports included American shows such as ''The [[Cheryl Ladd]] Special'', ''[[Here's Lucy]]'', ''Ride on Stranger'', ''[[Falcon Crest]]'', ''[[Miami Vice]]'', ''[[Benson (TV series)|Benson]]''," Dallas", ''[[Magnum, P.I.]]'', ''The [[Paul Anka]] Show'', ''[[Remington Steele]]'', ''[[Murder, She Wrote]]'', ''[[Spenser for Hire]]'', ''[[The Cosby Show]]'', ''[[The Twilight Zone]]'', ''[[The Days and Nights of Molly Dodd]]'', ''[[Evening Extra]]'', ''[[Turning Point (TV series)|Turning Point]]'', ''On the Town'', ''[[Our House (1986 TV series)|Our House]]'', ''[[The Ray Bradbury Theatre]]''. British imports included ''[[Are You Being Served?]]'', ''[[Codename Icarus]]'', ''[[The Paper Lads]]'', ''[[Dempsey & Makepeace]]'', ''[[Tomorrow's World]]'' and ''[[Executive Stress]]''.{{cite web|url=http://tvlistings.thetvroomplus.com/?id=6:ca|title= RTÃ 1 TV Lisings 1989 - 1989|publisher=The TV Room|page=10|accessdate=24 April 2010}} In 1988 RTÃ Two re-branded as Network 2 which saw RTÃ move many of its children's and imported shows over to Network 2. ====1990 - 1999==== Children's shows remained on RTÃ 1 on Saturday morning for most of the 1990s imports included ''[[DuckTales]]'', ''[[Batman (TV series)|Batman]]'', ''[[Family Ties]]'', ''The [[Disney]] Hour'', ''[[Katts and Dog]]'', ''[[Nellie the Elephant (TV series)|Nellie the Elephant]]'' and ''[[The Pink Panther Show]]''. P.]]'', ''[[The Sullivans]]'', ''[[Santa Barbara (TV series)|Santa Barbara]]'', ''[[Randall and Hopkirk (Deceased)]]'', ''[[Take the High Road]]'', ''[[Forever Green]]'' and ''[[Highway to Heaven]]''. Educational programming at the time moved to Sunday morning including ''Espana Viva'', ''A Vous La France'' and ''Russian Language and People''.{{cite web|url=http://tvlistings.thetvroomplus.com/?id=6:ca|title=RTÃ One TV Listings 1990 - 1999|publisher=The TV Room|page=20|accessdate=24 April 2010}} 28 January 1991 saw the last episode of cult favourite ''[[Twin Peaks]]'' broadcast on RTÃ 1.{{cite web|url=http://tvlistings.thetvroomplus.com/listing-803.html|title=RTE One TV listings for 21/01/1991|publisher=The TV Room|page=1|accessdate=24 April 2010}} ====2000 - 2009==== Since the late 1990s RTÃ One's Prime Time schedule is made up of nearly 100% Irish programming, some exceptions include ''[[EastEnders]]'', ''The Midweek Movie'', ''The Big Big Movie'' and with a few classic repeats intermittently such as ''[[Fawlty Towers]]'' and ''[[Only Fools and Horses]]''. Since 2001 RTÃ One's daytime imports are made up of Soap Operas (such as the Australian soap's ''[[Neighbours]]'' and ''[[Home and Away]]'', the New Zealand soap ''[[Shortland Street]]'', the English soaps ''[[Doctors (2000 TV series)|Doctors]]'' and ''[[EastEnders]]''), American Detective Dramas (including the Highly repeatable ''[[Murder, She Wrote]]'') and since 2001 they have broadcast American daytime chat shows (including ''[[The Doctors (2008 TV series)|The Doctors]]'' and ''[[Doctor Phil]]'', they also broadcast ''[[The Oprah Winfrey Show|Oprah]]'' but that is now shown on ''[[TV3 (Ireland)|TV3]]''). During the 2000s RTÃ broadcast the ITV soap [[The Bill]] over 2 half hour episode Monday to Friday at 17:30, rather than the original hour long episodes. American dramas broadcast from 2000 to 2009 included ''[[ER (TV series)|ER]]'', ''[[The Practice]]'', ''[[Damages]]'', ''[[Shark (TV series)|Shark]]'', ''[[Angel (TV series)|Angel]], ''[[Two and a Half Men]]'', ''[[Medium (TV series)|Medium]]'', ''[[Mad Men]]'', and ''[[The West Wing]]''. English Drama's ''[[Spooks]]'' and ''[[Waking the Dead (TV series)|Waking the Dead]]'' have also aired on the Channel.{{cite web|url=http://tvlistings.thetvroomplus.com/?id=6:ca|title=RTÃ One TV Listings 2000 - 2009|publisher=The TV Room|page=3|accessdate=24 April 2010}} ====2010 - Date==== RTÃ One Launched their 2010 schedule with ''[[The Mentalist]]'' as a replacement for the long running Sunday night drama ''[[ER (TV series)|ER]]''. Other imports included ''Who Do You Think You Are?'' both the [[Who Do You Think You Are? (British TV series)|British]] and [[Who Do You Think You Are? (U.S. TV series)|American]] versions which coincided with their broadcast of the Irish version. On the 4th of August 2010 RTÃ launched their schedule which included imports ''[[Mad Men]]'' and ''[[Masterchef Australia]]''.{{cite web|url=http://tvsales.rte.ie/autumn/acquisitions.html|title=Acquisitions|date=5 August 2010|publisher=RTÃ Sales|accessdate=6 August 2010}} RTÃ One also broadcast ''[[Packed To The Rafters]]'', ''[[The Bill]]'', ''[[Medium (TV series)|Medium]]'' and ''[[McLeod's Daughters]]''. Daytime repeats now include [[Desperate Housewives]], [[The Good Wife (TV series)|The Good Wife]] and [[Brothers & Sisters (2006 TV series)|Brothers & Sisters]]. ==On-air identity== Throughout the years, RTÃ One has gone through many changes to its on-air identity, mostly in tune with the changing of the statutory logo of the cooperation that operates it, as in the early years. The average life of an RTÃ One [[television ident|ident]] is around three years, with modifications and changes along the way. ===1961 to 1978=== [[Image:RTE Logo 1961.jpg|thumb|right|Original TeilifÃ­s Ãireann logo]] [[Image:RTE Logo 1969.jpg|thumb|right|Original RaidiÃ³ TeilifÃ­s Ãireann logo]] Early idents prominently featured the original name of ''TelefÃ­s Ãireann'', and the [[Brigid's cross|St. Brigid's Cross]] which would become the symbol of the channel for years to come. In 1966, the radio and television stations adopted the common brand ''Radio TelifÃ­s Ãireann'' in line with the renamed broadcasting authority,[http://www.acts.ie/zza7y1966.1.html#zza7y1966s4 No. 7/1966: BROADCASTING AUTHORITY (AMENDMENT) ACT, 1966] and the ident used the [[initialism]] RTE, with no [[sÃ­neadh fada]] [[diacritic]] over the E of ''Ãireann''. The 1995 logo was the first to read ''RTÃ'' rather than ''RTE''. ===1978 to 1988=== As colour television was introduced. The station became ''RTE 1'' in 1978, when [[RTE 2]] was launched. A new ident in 1980 featured the characters "RTE1" wrapped within a stylized St. Brigid's Cross. This design, along with a variant with slight colour changes, were used until 1987, when another ident was formed. The ident featured the St. Brigid's Cross, which was blended into the "T" in "RTE". The "T" also resembled the digit 1 of the channel's number. The first time the channel left out the St. Brigid's Cross from its idents was in 1989, when an ident that featured the letters "RTE" revolving around the number 1, against an emerald green background, was released. This was to last until 1993, with minor revisions. ===1993 to 1998=== 1993 saw the return of the St. Brigid's cross to the RTÃ One Idents. It was seen floating across a stone background that resembled cave walls. This ident lasted until 1995, when a new ident that featured the new corporate logo was released. The logo also saw the return of the fada on RTÃ's "E" in a stylistic manner. The ident started with a misty background, with the new RTÃ logo peering through, eventually fading into the station's name. At the beginning, the St. Brigid's Cross was left out, but it was restored to the screens after viewers complained. ===1998 to 2000=== 1998 saw the end of single ident templates for RTÃ One. In a rebranding, three idents were released, and all revolved around nature. The St. Brigid's Cross continued to grace the screen, but now has to share its airtime with other idents. During this time, a special ident for overnight programmes and the celebration of the milliennium were created. The original three idents were gradually phased out in late 2000, but was featured in other new idents thereafter. ===2000 to 2003=== In September 2000, a new set of idents were gradually introduced to RTÃ One, with all the old idents from 1998 phased out by December of that year. The new idents featured Irish places and people, and all were set to a common set of background music. One of the original three idents were featured in seven of the new idents, subtly playing in the background. A promotions video, featuring snippets of the idents, was shown as a part of the campaign. ===2003 to 2006=== On 1 September 2003, RTÃ One launched a new set of idents, with a new style for its "RTÃ One" branding. The ident showed Ireland's old face first, and then flashed into images of Ireland today. New ident sets were introduced in 2004, and deviated from the "Ireland Old And New" theme. Subsequent edits on the original idents also took away the "old" element from the idents. As was before, a promotions video was aired before the launch of the new idents. ===2006 to present=== At 6:00 am on 3 November 2006, RTÃ One unveiled its basic set of new idents, designed by [[Red Bee Media]]. ==RTÃ One Main Analogue Transmitters== :''Main article:'' [[RTÃ Network Limited]] {| class="wikitable" |- !
